snp4.13:0.2.eng: The Longer Discourse on Arrayed for Battle

snp4.13:1.1.eng: “Regarding those who maintain their own view,

snp4.13:1.2.eng: disputing that, ‘This is the only truth’:

snp4.13:1.3.eng: are all of them subject only to criticism,

snp4.13:1.4.eng: or do some also win praise for that?”

snp4.13:2.1.eng: “That is a small thing, insufficient for peace,

snp4.13:2.2.eng: these two fruits of dispute, I say.

snp4.13:2.3.eng: Seeing this, one ought not dispute,

snp4.13:2.4.eng: looking for sanctuary in the land of no dispute.
snp4.13:2.4.comm: If we render khema as “security” and bhūmi as “stage” then we miss the metaphor. Abhi-√pas is found at AN 3.39:11.4 and AN 5.57:15.4 where it has a similar sense of “looking forward to”.

snp4.13:3.1.eng: One who knows does not get involved

snp4.13:3.2.eng: with any of the many different conventions.

snp4.13:3.3.eng: Why would the uninvolved get involved,

snp4.13:3.4.eng: since they do not believe <j>based on the seen or the heard?

snp4.13:4.1.eng: Those who champion ethics <j>speak of purity through self-control;

snp4.13:4.2.eng: having undertaken a vow, they stick to it:

snp4.13:4.3.eng: ‘Let us train right here, then we will be pure.’

snp4.13:4.4.eng: Claiming to be skilled, they are led on to future lives.

snp4.13:5.1.eng: If they fall away from their precepts and vows,

snp4.13:5.2.eng: they tremble, having failed in their task.

snp4.13:5.3.eng: They pray and long for purity,

snp4.13:5.4.eng: like one who has lost their caravan <j>while journeying far from home.

snp4.13:6.1.eng: But having given up all precepts and vows,

snp4.13:6.2.eng: and these deeds blameworthy or blameless;

snp4.13:6.4.comm: The Niddesa’s explanation of santi as “view” is not plausible. I follow Norman.

snp4.13:7.1.eng: Relying on mortification in disgust at sin,
snp4.13:7.1.comm: Reading tapūpanissāya; see Bodhi’s note 1961. Since in prose tapojigucchāusually occur together, I treat them as such here.

snp4.13:7.2.pli: Atha vāpi diṭṭhaṃ va sutaṃ mutaṃ vā;
snp4.13:7.2.eng: or else on what is seen, heard, or thought,

snp4.13:7.3.eng: they moan that purification <j>comes through heading upstream,
snp4.13:7.3.comm: MN 102:11.3 shows that uddhaṁsarā is a term used of those who look to salvation “upstream” in a future life. Anutthunati rather consistently means “bemoans”, and here I think it is used in a disparaging way of those who, suffering under self-inflicted mortification, moan that purity is just around the corner.

snp4.13:7.4.eng: not rid of craving for life after life.

snp4.13:8.1.eng: For one who longs there are muttered prayers,

snp4.13:8.2.eng: and trembling too over ideas they have formed.

snp4.13:8.3.eng: But one here for whom there is no passing away <j>or reappearing:

snp4.13:8.4.pli: Sa kena vedheyya kuhiṃ va jappe”.
snp4.13:8.4.eng: why would they tremble? For what would they pray?”

snp4.13:9.1.eng: “The very same teaching that some say is ‘ultimate’,

snp4.13:9.3.eng: Which of these doctrines is true,

snp4.13:9.4.eng: for they all claim to be an expert?”

snp4.13:10.1.eng: “They say their own teaching is perfect,

snp4.13:10.2.eng: while the teaching of others is inferior.

snp4.13:10.4.eng: each saying their own conventions are the truth.

snp4.13:11.1.eng: If someone else’s disparagement makes you inferior,

snp4.13:11.2.eng: no-one in any teaching would be distinguished.

snp4.13:11.3.eng: For each of them says the other’s teaching is lacking,

snp4.13:12.1.eng: But if they honor their own teachings
snp4.13:12.1.comm: Here I follow Ñāṇadīpa, who takes the whole verse as a conditional argument, whereas Bodhi and Norman treat each couplet separately. I think the verse is making the argument that each ascetic bases their teaching on their own experience, and so if their teachings were equally valid, then purity would be attained by many (mutually exclusive) means.

snp4.13:12.2.eng: just as they praise their own journeys,

snp4.13:12.3.eng: then all doctrines would be equally valid,

snp4.13:12.4.eng: and purity would be specific to them.
snp4.13:12.4.comm: Cp. Dhp 165:5, where an apparently similar idea (suddhī asuddhi paccattaṁ) is Buddhist. There, the emphasis is on the personal realization of the teachings, here on different, contradictory, realizations.

snp4.13:13.1.eng: After judging among the teachings, <j>a brahmin has adopted nothing

snp4.13:13.3.eng: That’s why they’ve gotten over disputes,

snp4.13:13.4.eng: for they see no other doctrine as best.

snp4.13:14.1.eng: Saying, ‘I know, I see, that’s how it is’,
snp4.13:14.1.comm: This signifies that we are speaking of ascetics who are, in Jayatilleke’s terms, “experientialists”, relying on their meditation experiences to justify their views. The same phrase describes the Buddha at AN 4.24:9.3.

snp4.13:14.2.eng: some believe that purity comes from view.

snp4.13:14.3.eng: But if they’ve really seen, <j>what use is that view to them?

snp4.13:14.4.eng: Overlooking what matters, <j>they say purity comes from another.
snp4.13:14.4.comm: Atisitvā is normally used in the sense of someone who “overlooks” the Buddha to seek answers elsewhere. In AN 3.39:4.1 it’s used in the sense of “overlooking oneself”, which Ñāṇadīpa takes as the relevant sense here.

snp4.13:15.1.eng: When a person sees, they see name and form,

snp4.13:15.2.eng: and having seen, they will know just these things.

snp4.13:15.3.eng: Gladly let them see much or little,

snp4.13:15.4.pli: Na hi tena suddhiṃ kusalā vadanti.
snp4.13:15.4.eng: for those who are skilled say this is no way to purity.

snp4.13:16.1.eng: It’s not easy to educate someone who is dogmatic,

snp4.13:16.2.eng: promoting a view they have formulated.

snp4.13:16.3.eng: Speaking of the beauty <j>in that on which they depend,
snp4.13:16.3.comm: Here the ascetic appears to refer to their meditative attainment. Compare the use of nissita at Snp 5.7.

snp4.13:16.4.eng: they talk of purity in accord with what they saw there.

snp4.13:17.1.eng: The brahmin does not get involved <j>with formulating and calculating;

snp4.13:17.2.eng: they’re not followers of views, <j>nor kinsmen of notions.
snp4.13:17.2.comm: To render ñāṇa here as knowledge would be a mistake.

snp4.13:17.3.eng: Having understood the many different conventions,

snp4.13:17.4.eng: they look on when others grasp.

snp4.13:18.1.eng: Having untied the knots here in the world,

snp4.13:18.2.eng: the sage takes no side among disputes.

snp4.13:18.4.eng: they don’t grasp when others grasp.

snp4.13:19.1.eng: Having given up former defilements <j>and not making new ones,

snp4.13:19.2.eng: not swayed by preference, <j>nor a proponent of dogma,
snp4.13:19.2.comm: Here, as at Snp 4.3:2.2, chanda is better read as “preference” than “desire”.

snp4.13:19.3.eng: that attentive one is released from views,

snp4.13:19.4.eng: not clinging to the world, <j>nor reproaching themselves.

snp4.13:20.1.eng: They are remote from all things

snp4.13:20.2.pli: Yaṃ kiñci diṭṭhaṃ va sutaṃ mutaṃ vā;

snp4.13:20.3.eng: With burden put down, the sage is released:

snp4.13:20.4.eng: not formulating, not abstaining, not longing.”

snp4.14:1.1.eng: “Great seer, I ask you, the Kinsman of the Sun,

snp4.14:1.2.eng: about seclusion and the state of peace.

snp4.14:1.3.eng: How, having seen, is a mendicant extinguished,

snp4.14:1.4.eng: not grasping anything in this world?”

snp4.14:2.1.eng: “They would cut off the idea, ‘I am the thinker,”

snp4.14:2.3.eng: “which is the root of all judgments <j>that emerge from proliferation.
snp4.14:2.3.comm: Reading mantā as an agent noun.

snp4.14:2.4.eng: Ever mindful, they would train to remove

snp4.14:3.1.eng: Regardless of what things they know,

snp4.14:3.3.eng: they wouldn’t be proud because of that,

snp4.14:3.4.pli: Na hi sā nibbuti sataṃ vuttā.
snp4.14:3.4.eng: for that is not quenching, say the good.

snp4.14:4.1.eng: They wouldn’t let that make them conceited,

snp4.14:4.2.eng: thinking themselves better or worse or alike.

snp4.14:4.3.comm: Reading puṭṭho as per variants.

snp4.14:4.4.comm: Compare vikappayeyya at Snp 4.4:6.4 and Snp 4.5:7.4.

snp4.14:5.1.eng: A mendicant would find peace inside themselves,

snp4.14:5.2.eng: and not seek peace from another.

snp4.14:5.3.eng: For one at peace inside themselves,

snp4.14:5.4.eng: there’s no picking up, whence putting down?

snp4.14:6.1.eng: Just as, in the middle of the ocean,

snp4.14:6.2.eng: no waves arise, it stays still;

snp4.14:6.3.eng: so too one unstirred is still—

snp4.14:6.4.eng: a mendicant would make <j>no pretension regarding anything.”

snp4.14:7.1.eng: “He whose eyes are open has explained

snp4.14:7.2.eng: the truth he witnessed, <j>where adversities are removed.

snp4.14:7.3.eng: Please now speak of the practice, sir,

snp4.14:7.4.eng: the monastic code and immersion in samādhi.”

snp4.14:8.2.eng: they’d turn their ears from village gossip.

snp4.14:8.3.eng: They wouldn’t be greedy for flavors,

snp4.14:8.4.eng: nor possessive about anything in the world.

snp4.14:9.2.eng: a mendicant would not lament at all.

snp4.14:9.3.eng: They wouldn’t pray for another life,

snp4.14:9.4.eng: nor tremble in the face of dangers.

snp4.14:10.1.eng: When they receive food and drink,

snp4.14:10.4.eng: nor worry about not getting them.

snp4.14:11.2.eng: they’d avoid remorse and not be negligent.

snp4.14:11.4.eng: in quiet places to sit and rest.

snp4.14:12.2.eng: but, being keen, <j>would apply themselves to wakefulness.

snp4.14:12.3.eng: They’d give up sloth, illusion, mirth, and play,

snp4.14:13.1.eng: They wouldn’t cast Artharvaṇa spells, <j>interpret dreams
snp4.14:13.1.comm: This is the only mention in the early Pali texts of the collection later known as the Arthavaveda. Niddesa explains it as casting harmful spells.

snp4.14:13.3.eng: My followers would not study ominous animal cries,
snp4.14:13.3.comm: Viruta is described in the Bṛhatsaṁhitā 88 as deciphering the cries of animals, especially those that are abnormal or out of place. It is similar to migacakka at 1.21.2. Gabbhakaraṇaṁ, here as inDN 1:1.26.2, is explained by Niddesa and commentary as the treatment of an impacted fetus to ease a difficult delivery.

snp4.14:13.4.eng: work as a doctor, or treat an impacted fetus.

snp4.14:14.2.eng: a mendicant would not gloat when praised.

snp4.14:14.3.eng: They’d cast aside greed and stinginess,

snp4.14:15.1.eng: They’d not stand for buying and selling;

snp4.14:15.2.eng: a mendicant would not speak ill at all.

snp4.14:15.3.eng: They wouldn’t linger in the village,

snp4.14:15.4.eng: nor cajole people from desire for profit.

snp4.14:16.1.eng: A mendicant would be no boaster,

snp4.14:17.1.eng: They wouldn’t be led into lying,

snp4.14:17.3.eng: And they’d never look down on another

snp4.14:17.4.eng: because of livelihood, wisdom, or precepts and vows.

snp4.14:18.1.eng: Though provoked from hearing much talk

snp4.14:18.2.eng: from ascetics saying all different things,
snp4.14:18.2.comm: The MS reading seems unlikely to me, these are not usually paired. More likely it’s an example of the Aṭṭhakavagga idiom where puthu refers to all the many different things said by ascetics.

snp4.14:18.4.eng: for the virtuous do not retaliate.

snp4.14:19.2.eng: inquiring, a mendicant would always train mindfully.

snp4.14:19.4.eng: they’d not be negligent in Gotama’s bidding.

snp4.14:20.1.eng: For he is the vanquisher, the unvanquished,

snp4.14:20.2.eng: seer of the truth as witness, not by hearsay—

snp4.14:20.3.eng: that’s why, being diligent, they would always train

snp4.15:1.1.eng: Peril stems from those who take up arms—

snp4.15:1.3.eng: I shall extol how I came to be

snp4.15:1.4.eng: stirred with a sense of urgency.

snp4.15:2.2.eng: like a fish in a little puddle.

snp4.15:2.3.eng: Seeing them at odds with each other,

snp4.15:3.4.comm: Osita (and osāna in the next line) convey both “occupy” and “end” in the sense of a place of rest at the end of a journey.

snp4.15:4.1.eng: Yet even in their settlement they were at odds—
snp4.15:4.1.comm: Here, tveva has a contrastive sense.

snp4.15:4.3.eng: Then I saw a dart there,

snp4.15:4.4.eng: so hard to see, stuck in the heart.

snp4.15:5.2.eng: you run around in all directions.

snp4.15:5.3.eng: But when that same dart has been plucked out,

snp4.15:5.4.eng: you neither run around nor sink down.

snp4.15:6.1.eng: (On that topic, the trainings are recited.)
snp4.15:6.1.comm: Agreeing with Norman that this line is likely a reciter’s remark. However, I take tattha as the locative of reference. “That topic” is the extraction of the dart, for which the remainder of the sutta gives practical guidelines.

snp4.15:6.2.eng: Whatever attachments there are in the world,

snp4.15:6.4.eng: Having pierced through sensual pleasures <j>in every way,

snp4.15:7.2.eng: free of deceit, and rid of slander;

snp4.15:7.3.eng: without anger, a sage would cross over

snp4.15:7.4.eng: the evils of greed and avarice.

snp4.15:8.1.eng: Prevail over sleepiness, sloth, and drowsiness,

snp4.15:9.2.eng: or get caught up in affection for form.

snp4.15:10.3.eng: Don’t grieve for what is running out,

snp4.15:10.4.eng: or get attached to things that pull you in.

snp4.15:11.1.eng: Greed, I say, is the great flood,

snp4.15:11.4.eng: the swamp of sensuality so hard to get past.

snp4.15:12.1.eng: The sage never strays from the truth;

snp4.15:12.2.eng: the brahmin stands on solid ground.

snp4.15:12.4.eng: they are said to be at peace.

snp4.15:13.1.eng: They have truly known, they’re a knowledge master,

snp4.15:13.2.eng: understanding the teaching, they are independent.

snp4.15:13.3.eng: They rightly proceed in the world,

snp4.15:14.1.eng: One who has crossed over sensuality here,

snp4.15:14.2.eng: the chain in the world so hard to get past,

snp4.15:14.4.eng: they’ve cut the strings, they’re no longer bound.

snp4.15:15.1.eng: What came before, let wither away,

snp4.15:15.2.eng: and after, let there be nothing.

snp4.15:15.3.eng: If you don’t grasp at the middle,

snp4.15:16.1.eng: One who has no sense of ownership

snp4.15:16.2.eng: in the whole realm of name and form,

snp4.15:16.3.eng: does not grieve for that which is not,

snp4.15:16.4.eng: they suffer no loss in the world.

snp4.15:17.1.eng: If you don’t think of anything

snp4.15:17.2.eng: as belonging to yourself or others,

snp4.15:17.4.eng: you won’t grieve, thinking ‘I don’t have it’.

snp4.15:18.3.eng: when asked about one who is unwavering,

snp4.15:18.4.eng: I declare that that is the benefit.

snp4.15:20.1.eng: A sage doesn’t speak of themselves as being

snp4.15:20.4.eng: they are neither ditching nor taking up.
